content: I think that this maybe even is a bit too trivial... but for a clash it could be working because you might even be able to one-line it in some languages :D

Submitting as clash because the solution's really trivial, but I really have no problem whatsoever with it moving to Puzzles if it's deemed to complex a statement for clashing. (Sorry, no clashing in a long time on my side, I might be out of touch)

Please be careful if you edit: I've put a few ZERO WIDTH NON-JOINERs around to help general appearance.
I edited the "x2" case, the first empty line was wrong.

My forecast is that it's going to be *very* dependent on who reads it. Some are going to panic at the very sight of "Rubik", others are going to recognize it for the trivial problem it is.

The more general point is: it's the easiest in the series, but it has its place. It's doable in clash (hence my submitting it there), but it could actually make sense to duplicate it to community puzzles once the others "can it be solved this way" are approved, to enable a more gradual difficulty slope.

My proposed sample solution is 78 characters (though I'll admit I didn't spend as much on it as I would have on a clash). How long is yours? :D
You are perfectly right. Will try to beat that... :D
I tried with a bad language for short code - C#. my minimum so far is 291. Perl users will have it easier...

Thanks!

For tracking: I just fixed the "UF edge flip" case, because, err... I'd forgotten to edge flip it :$
